ABSTRACT 27
Silica-rich rice husk (RH) is an abundant and sustainable agricultural waste. The recovery of value 28 added products from RH or its ash to explore an economic way for the valorization of agricultural 29 wastes have attracted wide attention. For instance, RH can be converted to biofuels and biochars 30 simultaneously via thermochemical processes. In general, the applications of RH biochars include 31 soil remediation, pollutants removal, silicon battery materials, etc. This review article concludes 32 recent progresses in the synthesis of RH-derived silicon materials for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) 33 applications. Silica nanomaterials produced from RH is initially discussed. RH amorphous silica 34 can also be fabricated to crystal silicon used for battery materials via wide-used magnesiothermic 35 reduction. However, the RH-derived Si nanoparticles suffer from a low coulombic efficiency in the 36 initial charge/discharge and limited cycle life as anode materials due to high surface reactions and 37 low thermodynamic stability. The synthesis of Si materials with nano/micro-hierarchical structure 38 would be an ideal way to improve their electrochemical performances. Embedding nano-Si into 39 3D conductive matrix is an effective way to improve the structure stability. Among the Si/carbon 40 composite materials, CNTs is a promising matrix due to the wired morphology, high electronic 41 conductivity, and robust structure. Additionally, CNTs can easily form 3D cross-linked conducting 42 networks, ensuring effective electron transportation among active particles. Si nanomaterials 43 with micro-hierarchical structures, in which CNTs are tightly intertwined between the RH-derived 44 Si nanoparticles, have been proved to be ideal LIBs anode materials. 45 46 KEYWORDS: rice husk (RH); biosilica; silicon; battery materials; magnesiothermic reduction 47 48 49 50 51 52 53 54 55
Page 2 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry

1. INTRODUCTION 56
1.1. Biogenic Silica 57
Silicon (Si), which is a ubiquitous and quantitatively the second most prominent element in the 58
earth crust after oxygen (O) [1], is released in soil by means of biological or chemical processes 59
[2-5]. Plants contribute significantly to the biogeochemical cycle of silicon in chemosphere [4, 5]. 60
They take up silicon from soil water in the form of water-soluble silicic acid (H4SiO4) [6], which is 61
polymerized and precipitated as amorphous silica (SiO2), frequently in close proximity to the 62
transpiration conduit. After plant death, SiO2 returns back to the soil and then the plant-decay 63
generates humic acid, which increases the weathering activity in soils. Bio-cycling of SiO2 in soil 64
also occurs via microbial activities that involve fungi, bacteria, and actinomycetes [7]. Therefore, 65
plants and microbes, through their intricate interplay with soil minerals, contribute appreciably 66
to the global silicon cycle [3-8]. 67 68 Silicon (Si) is accumulated mainly in the form of phytoliths in plants [9], consisting primarily 69
of the amorphous hydrated silica (SiO2 with 5-15% H2O). Phytoliths-containing plants include 70
dicots (e.g., Myrtaceae, Casuarinaceae, Proteaceae, Xanthorrhoeaceae, Mimosaceae), 71
monocots (e.g., Cyperaceae, Gramineae, Palmae), conifers (e.g., Pinaceae, Taxodiaceae), and 72
sphenophytes/scouring rushes (e.g., Equisetaceae) [10]. The ash content of Equisetaceae 73
and Gramineae/Poaceae may consist of 50-70% silica [11]. Some polyamines, carbohydrates, 74
proteins, and glycoproteins from diatoms and sponges are capable of polymerizing silicic 75
acid at neutral to acidic pH [12-14]. Some plant carbohydrates and proteins would play a key 76
role in biogenic silica polymerization [15-18]. In the biosphere, silica is usually accumulated 77
predominantly in the form of amorphous silica (opal or silica gel) [9]. 78

ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry

1.2. Rice Husk (RH) Silica 79
Rice (Oryza sativa), a member of the family Gramineae, typically constitutes 20-22% of its total 80
produce in the form of RH, and a great deal of RH is presently disposed by rice mill industry as a 81
waste. Interestingly, the highest SiO2 content in rice is observed in its husk, which varies from 8.7% 82
to 12.1%, averaging close to 10.6% [19]. However, SiO2 present in RH is in a hydrated amorphous 83
form similar to that present in most of the other entities in the biosphere [20]. The biological 84
formation of inorganic materials (e.g., silica materials) with complex forms (i.e. biominerals) is a 85
widespread phenomenon in nature [21]. In recent decades, the recovery of value added products 86
from RH or its ash to explore an economic way for the valorization of agricultural wastes have 87
attracted wide attention [22]. However, there is lack of a comprehensive article on the synthesis 88
and application of value-added silicon materials derived from RH. Therefore, this review article 89
presents recent progresses in the synthesis of RH-derived silicon materials for lithium-ion battery 90
applications. 91 92 2. RICE HUSK SILICA PRODUCTION 93
Silica is recognized as an extremely important inorganic material and is extensively used for a 94
wide range of commercial applications such as molecular sieves, catalysts, and in biomedical and 95
electrical applications [23-29]. In general, porous inorganic microstructures are of interest as low 96
density and thermally stable particles, and as mechanically resistant encapsulation structures. 97
The chemical syntheses of silica materials are not only relatively expensive and eco-hazardous, 98
but also require strict synthesis conditions. In contrast, biosilicification by living organisms such 99
as cyanobacteria, diatoms, sponges, and plants proceeds under mild physiological conditions and 100
results in a diversity of complex and hierarchical biogenic silica nanostructural frameworks [9]. 101
Page 4 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
5
102
Silica-rich rice husk ash (RHA) can be achieved by thermal treatment at elevated temperatures or 103
it can be extracted from RH in the form of sodium silicate by a solvent extraction method. In most 104
applications, RHA is more favorable compared to RH. RHA is a general term describing all forms of 105
the ash produced from RH. In practice, the form of RHA obtained varies considerably according to 106
the temperature. Silica in the RHA undergoes structural transformations based on the conditions 107
(time, temperature, etc.) of combustion. Amorphous silica is formed at 550-800 o C and crystalline 108
silica occurs at temperatures greater than this [30]. These types of silica have different properties 109
and it is significant to produce RH silica of the correct specification for the particular end use [31]. 110
In general, the structure and properties of RH silica are sensitive to the methods. The forms of RH 111
silica are different from amorphous to distinct crystal phases depending on the temperature or 112
chemical treatments [32]. Fig. 1 summarizes the methods for producing silica from RH, including 113
impurities removal before and after thermal processes. Of the different synthesis methods, the 114
chemical method consisting of simple acid leaching and post annealing is one of the most simple 115
and successful techniques to synthesize the ultrafine SiO2 nanoparticles from RHA. 116
Page 5 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
6
Leaching of RH with different chemical solutions (e.g., HCl, H2SO4, H3PO4, HNO3, HF, NH4OH, and 120
NaOH) before thermal processes under different conditions (e.g., temperature, time) can be so 121
effective in accelerating the hydrolysis of cellulose and hemicelluloses in RH and removing most 122
of the metallic impurities, which allows producing white-color silica completely, with high surface 123
area [33-38]. Recently, Zeng and Bai [39] prepared the polyethyleneimine (PEI)-functionalized 124
hierarchically porous silica nanoparticles from RH via a simple template-free method. Compared 125
with traditional alkaline fusion and surfactant-templating methods for preparing waste-derived 126
porous silica materials, this method had specific important advantages in being an inexpensive, 127
and energy-saving process with faster production rate. In this work, the addition of hydrofluoric 128
acid (HF) followed by ammonium hydroxide corresponding to the formation of (NH4)2SiF6 salt can 129
serve as an effective porogen, so high-temperature is unnecessary for extraction SiO2 from RH. 130 131 Apart from the synthesis conditions, the types of silica precursors can influence the properties of 132
silica materials. Sankar et al. [40] synthesized the silica nanopowders from different RH sources 133
(as shown in Fig. 2). The prepared silica nanoparticles had a uniform surface morphology with 134
respect to the particle size distribution, and the sizes of silica nanoparticles decreased from 50 135
nm (sticky RHA) to 10 nm (brown RHA). The mesoporous silica nanopowder synthesized from 136
brown RHA had the lowest particle size distribution and the highest surface area. Besides, various 137
sizes ranging from nanometer to micrometer of amorphous spherical silica particles could be 138
controllably synthesized from RH [40]. 139
Page 6 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
7
chemical extraction, the high-yield amorphous silica can be recovered from pyrolysis char. More 145
significantly, the activated carbon with high specific surface area can also be produced by using 146
physical or chemical activation (as illustrated in Fig. 3) [41]. Co-production of silica with other 147
valuable products mainly including activated carbon, biofuels and lignocellulosic components 148
would become the most promising way for RH valorization [41-45]. 149
Page 7 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
8
Rice grows by taking in silicic acid as well as CO2, water and various minerals [45]. As illustrated in 154
Fig. 4, rice deposits amorphous silica on their cell walls, forming silica-cuticle and silica-cellulose 155
double layers on the surface of leaves, stems and husks [46, 47]. Therefore, amorphous silica on 156
the cell walls of RH can play as a role of the natural template for the formation of porous carbon 157
(PC), as well as silica recycling. Tabata et al. [48] developed an environmentally friendly process 158
for synthesis of value-added hierarchical porous carbon (HPC) material, comprising micro-, meso- 159
and macro-pores by using unique structural cell assemblies of RH. Noteworthy, steam activation 160
of PC contributed to the deepening of the meso- and micro-pores with respect to the formation 161
of HPC with low-toxicity and superior in vivo properties. In addition, it can be applied to many 162
significant applications not in the electronic and industrial fields but in the medical field for use 163
as adsorbents, drug delivery and bio-interface materials, and scaffolds for cell incubation [48]. 164

In addition, RH silica materials with specific morphologies and structures can be synthesized for 169
several particular applications [49-52]. Wang et al. [49] explored the intrinsic morphology and 170
microstructure of the biosilica in RH by controlling the pretreatment and reaction conditions to 171
maintain their original structure. Here, porous silica nanoparticles with narrow size distribution 172
and high surface area were initially prepared from the HCl-treated RH by means of controlled 173
pyrolysis. Subsequently, the semi-crystalline porous silica frameworks with tunable pore sizes 174
were formed by doping the silica nanoparticles with K + cations and tailoring pyrolysis conditions 175
(as illustrated in Fig. 5). Compared with amorphous porous silica, the synthesized porous silica 176
frameworks have wide applications and exhibit superior performance because of the increased 177
crystallinity and structural integrity [49]. In general, RHA has wide range of applications, including 178
the fabrication of silica gels, silicon chip, silica-carbon composite, construction materials, catalysts, 179
zeolites, battery materials, graphene, energy storage/capacitor, carbon capture, as well as in drug 180
delivery vehicles [51]. 181
Page 9 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
10
3. BATTERY MATERIALS 186
Silicon with high-purity and crystalline structures is often required for the preparation of battery 187
materials. The conventional process of producing silicon is relatively expensive [53]. Thus, many 188
efforts are being directed to develop a low-cost, high-volume and commercially feasible process 189
for producing high purity silicon in electrical applications [54-56]. One such process involves RHA 190
reduction to silicon. Several approaches have been developed to produce silicon from RH. For 191
instance, amorphous silica can be reduced to silicon via carbothermal reduction at relatively high 192
temperatures [57, 58]. Marchal et al. [58] synthesized the solar grade silicon (≈99.9999% pure) 193
from RHA as a biogenic silica source. RHA is initially purified using acid milling/boiling water wash 194
purification steps and pelletization followed by carbothermal reduction using an experimental 50 195
kW electric arc furnace (EAF) operated at 1700-2100 o C in batch mode. In addition, reduction of 196
amorphous silica to silicon by metallic metals has been studied extensively. The metallic elements 197
of Mg, Ca, Al and Ti can reduce SiO2 at comparatively lower temperature and forms mixtures of 198
condensed phase products [59-62]. The overall reactions with corresponding free energy change 199
and adiabatic temperature rise per mole of silicon are shown in Table 1. 200 201 Thermic reduction of SiO2 can be accomplished via the above-mentioned mechanisms including 202
carbothermal, magnesiothermic, aluminothermic, and calciothermic reduction. Carbothermal 203
reduction often utilizes EAF operating at 2000 o C and is the primary mode for metallurgical silicon 204
production [63]. However, this process is generally very energy intensive and liquefies the silicon, 205
thus destroying any original morphology of SiO2. Recently, magnesiothermic reduction has gained 206
much attention due to its lower operating temperatures (650 o C). Typically, Mg powder is placed 207
adjacent to SiO2 powder and the furnace is heated until Mg vaporizes. However, this reduction 208
Page 10 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
11
scheme produces zonal variations in composition with Mg2Si forming near the Mg powder, Si in 209
the middle, and unreacted SiO2 furthest from the Mg [64]. Luo et al. [65] proved the addition of 210
NaCl to the reduction process aids in scavenging the large amount of heat generated during this 211
highly exothermic reaction. NaCl effectively halts the reaction temperature rise at 801 o C during 212
fusion, preventing the reaction from surpassing the melting point of silicon and thus aiding in 213
preserving the original SiO2 morphology. Favors et al. [66] synthesized the porous nano-silicon via 214
a scalable heat scavenger-assisted magnesiothermic reduction of sand. The addition of NaCl, as 215
an effective heat scavenger for the highly exothermic magnesiothermic reduction, promotes the 216
formation of an interconnected 3D network of nano-silicon with a thickness of 8-10 nm. Herein, 217
carbon coated nano-silicon electrodes can achieve remarkable electrochemical performance with 218
a capacity of 1024 mAhg -1 at 2 Ag -1 after 1000 cycles. This environmentally benign, abundant, 219
and low cost SiO2 source allows for the production of nano-silicon with excellent electrochemical 220
performance as an anode material for Li-ion batteries [66]. 221 222 Mishra et al. [56] investigated the purification of silicon through calcium reduction of RHA. They 223
mixed RHA obtained at 500 o C and calcium thoroughly in stoichiometric proportions. Then the 224
mixture was reduced at 720 o C. The reduced product leached with HNO3 and HF to achieve high 225
purity of 99.9% silicon. Obtaining silicon of (99.9999%) purity by reducing RHA with magnesium 226
at temperature of 800 o C was followed by several successive acid (mixtures of HF, H2SO4 and HCl) 227
leaching treatments. With acid treatment, it is possible to remove MgO, Mg2Si and unreacted Mg 228
as by-products. Larbi [59] reported that by utilization of pellet of RHA with Mg content 5 wt.% in 229
excess of stoichiometry requirement and heating at 900 o C under the flowing argon, a maximum 230
silicon yield can be achieved. The fine silicon nanocrystals was also formed via magnesiothermic 231
Page 11 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
12
reaction. The reduction of SiO2 to form Si has obtained popularity since the three-dimensionally 232
structured Si replicas could be produced from parent SiO2 diatom by magnesiothermic reduction 233
[60]. Magnesiothermic reduction of various types of silica/carbon (SiO2/C) composites has been 234
frequently used to synthesize silicon/carbon (Si/C) composites and silicon carbide (SiC) materials, 235
which are of great interest in the applications of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and nonmetal oxide 236
ceramics, respectively [61]. Mg2Si has been considered as intermediates of Si in magnesiothermic 237
reduction of SiO2 [67, 68]. On the basis of these facts, the kinetic product of Si can be formed if 238
conversion from SiO2 to Si is completed before the silicon intermediates reach carbon. In other 239
words, Si can be synthesized if insufficient diffusion of Si intermediates to carbon is prompted. 240 241 Based on the methods discussed above, unique nanostructures of amorphous silica derived from 242
abundant biogenic silica sources (e.g., RH) can be reduced to silicon or silicon-carbon composites 243
in high-value LIBs applications [69-75]. Table 2 shows the reported works on RH-derived silicon 244
materials in LIBs applications. Generally, silicon materials have relatively high potential to be used 245
as the LIBs anodes compared with silica composites. Jung et al. [69] synthesized nanostructured 246
Si from RH via magnesiothermic reduction process. After that, 3D porous Si was obtained after an 247
additional two-stage acid etching process (as illustrated in Fig. 6). This work proved that RH can 248
be employed to produce Si with an ideal porous nanostructure for high-capacity LIB anodes. Its 249
interconnected nanoporous structure, developed via natural evolution for efficient cultivation of 250
rice, can resolve important issues in the Si anode operation, enabling excellent cycling and power 251
performance. 252
Page 12 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
13
from RH. As shown in Fig. 7c-g, RH were first converted to nano-SiO2 by thermal decomposition, 265
followed by magnesiothermic reduction to produce nano-Si (Fig. 7a). This innovative method has 266
several advantages: (i) the recovered silicon inherits the intrinsic and unique nanostructure of the 267
RH silica, allowing for excellent battery performance by mitigating pulverization; (ii) RH is an 268
abundant and sustainable silica source; (iii) the whole process is facile, energy-efficient, and easy 269
to scale-up; and (iv) the overall process does not use expensive silica precursors or reagents. And 270
Mg is produced by electrolytic process with a relatively low cost. Mg can be regenerated from the 271
electrolysis of MgCl2 (Fig. 7c). Therefore, this green process only consumes HCl and converts it to 272
Cl2 after the electrolysis. 273

magnesiothermic reduction process. Subsequently, silicon nanoparticles were used to prepare a 283
binder-free composite of Si-graphene as an anode material for LIBs (as illustrated in Fig. 8). The 284
Si-graphene composite yielded an initial capacity of 1000 mA h/g at high applied current density 285
of 1000 mA/g. In summary, all these studies open up the use of waste materials especially for 286
agricultural wastes (e.g., RH) as a sustainable source in advanced technology applications. 287

Praneetha et al. [75] proposed a rapid microwave assisted approach to extract SiO2 from various 292
agricultural residues such as bamboo culm (BC), RH, and sugarcane bagasse (SB) followed by a 293
magnesiothermic reduction of SiO2 into Si within 30 min at temperatures below 650 o C without 294
using any reducing gas atmosphere. This reduction reactor inside the microwave muffle furnace 295
can be given by the SiC passive heating element (PHE) plates by absorbing microwave radiation 296
and subsequent transfer of heat to the reactants with increase in reaction kinetics during raw 297
material (SB, BC, and RH) ashing and magnesiothermic reduction processes (Fig. 9A). Si-based 298
nanohybrids were produced by a microwave assisted solvothermal (MW-ST) process that offer a 299
uniform heating of polar solvent by absorbing microwave energy followed by heating (Fig. 9B). 300
The pristine Si and their nanohybrids with carbon, multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNT), and 301
graphene had been proved as a high capacity anode for LIBs for energy storage applications [75]. 302
Page 15 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
16
The fabrication of Si anode materials with biomass enables the effective utilization of agricultural 308
residues in battery industries, despite the electrochemical performances of these as-synthesized 309
Si materials still require improvements. The RH-derived Si nanoparticles always suffer from a low 310
coulombic efficiency in the initial charge/discharge and limited cycle life as anode materials due 311
to high surface reactions and low thermodynamic stability. Based on the reported works, the 312
fabrication of Si nanomaterials with nano/micro-hierarchical structure would be an ideal way to 313
improve their electrochemical performances, since the materials on the micrometer size possess 314
a good thermodynamic stability upon cycling. Embedding nano-Si into three-dimensional (3D) 315
conductive matrix is an effective way to improve the structure stability and form stable solid 316
electrolyte interphase (SEI) films on surfaces. Among various Si/carbon composite materials 317
[76-80], carbon nanotube (CNT) has been considered as a promising matrix because of the wired 318
morphology, high electronic conductivity, and robust structure [81]. Additionally, it is easy for CNT 319
to form 3D cross-linked conducting networks, ensuring effective electron transportation among 320
active particles [76]. Consequently, Si anode materials with nano/micro-hierarchical structure, in 321
which CNTs are tightly intertwined between the RH-derived Si nanoparticles, are supposed to be 322
ideal anode materials for LIBs. 323 324 More recently, Zhang et al. [82] fabricated Si/nitrogen-doped carbon/carbon nanotube (SNCC) 325
nano/micro-structured spheres by using a polyacrylonitrile (PAN) assisted electrospray method. 326
RH-derived Si nanoparticles on the sizes of 50 nm were homogeneously dispersed and embedded 327
into the N-doped carbon matrix intertwined and threaded by CNT cross-linking networks, forming 328
micro-spheres with the diameters of 3.270.8 μm. Given the high electronic conductivity, robust 329
structure, and improved surface/interface stability, SNCC spheres can exhibit high cycling stability 330
Page 16 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
17
(1031 mA h g -1 at 0.5 A g -1 after 100 cycles) and excellent rate capability as anode materials for 331
LIBs (Fig. 10). The synthesis of SNCC nano/micro-structured spheres is schematically depicted in 332
Fig. 10A. Firstly, RH were pretreated to obtain high purity nano-SiO2, which was then reduced to 333
RH-Si nanoparticles by magnesiothermic reduction. Subsequently, RH-Si nanoparticles and CNTs 334
were dispersed in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution containing PAN through adding a small 335
amount of sodium citrate to improve the dispersity of CNTs in DMF solution [83]. Finally, uniform 336
SNCC nano/micro-structured spheres were obtained through electrospray method accompanying 337
further carbonization process. 338
339
Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of electrode with the SNCC spheres at a scan rate of 0.5 mV s -1 are 340
shown in Fig. 10B. A broad cathodic peak appeared at 0.68 V in the first cycle and disappeared in 341
latter cycles, which results from the decomposition of electrolyte and the formation of SEI films, 342
leading to initial irreversible capacity [83]. In the next CV curves, there is a main cathodic peak at 343
0.18 V (the lithiation reaction of Si to form LixSi alloy), while the other two peaks at 0.36 and 0.52 344
V at the anodic sweep is assigned to delithiation process of LixSi [84]. The SNCC spheres have a 345
long flat discharge plateau at 0.09 V in the first cycle (Fig. 10C, the characteristic plateau of the 346
lithiation of crystalline Si) [85]. The SNCC spheres show promising stability and reversibility even 347
though 10 mV is used as the cutoff voltage. In the latter cycles, the crystalline Si transformed to 348
amorphous Si and exhibited the representative charge/discharge profiles of amorphous Si [84]. 349
Nevertheless, a low initial coulombic efficiency (CE) of 46% for RH-Si electrode was obtained with 350
a high initial discharge specific capacity of 3006 mA h g -1 . However, the initial discharge specific 351
capacity of SNCC spheres reached 2062 mA h g -1 with a high CE of 72%, demonstrating that 352
Page 17 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
18
incorporation of Si nanoparticles into micro-sized hierarchical carbon matrix could significantly 353
reduce the undesired surface reaction. When cycling at the current density of 0.5 A g -1 , the SNCC 354
spheres could maintain 92% of the initial charge specific capacity after 50 cycles, and deliver a 355
specific capacity as high as 1031 mA h g -1 even after 100 cycles with a high CE around 100% (Fig. 356
10D), nearly twice higher than the theoretical capacity of graphite (372 mA h g -1 ). However, the 357
specific capacity of RH-Si counterpart sharply decreased to below 200 mA h g -1 after 17 cycles. 358
And the SNCC spheres can keep the microsphere morphology well after 100 full charge/discharge 359
cycles, indicating their electrochemically stable structure toward Li + intercalation/extraction. The 360
mass loading of the SNCC electrode entirely located between 0.8 and 1.0 mg cm -2 , much higher 361
than that of the previous reported RH-derived Si-based electrodes (0.1-0.3 mg cm -2 ) [69, 72, 74]. 362
Due to the 3D conductive networks built by N-doped carbon/CNT, the SNCC spheres electrode 363
also exhibits an excellent rate performance (Fig. 10E). At the current density of 0.1 and 1 A g -1 , 364
the SNCC spheres electrode can achieve a specific capacity of 1460 and 978 mA h g -1 , respectively, 365
corresponding to a capacity retention of 67% at high rate. Moreover, a specific capacity of 1236 366
mA h g -1 is recovered when the current density is lowered to 0.2 A g -1 , showing high reversibility. 367
Such a favorable electrochemical performance is probably attributed to the elegant structural 368
design. On one hand, the carbon matrix built by CNTs and N-doped carbon layers can provide 369
sufficient conductive pathways for electron diffusion and fast lithium ion transportation, enabling 370
a high specific capacity at large charge/discharge current; on the other hand, the flexible CNTs 371
and the robust N-doped carbon framework function as structural reinforcement can maintain the 372
whole integrity to overcome mechanical breaking during the huge volume changes of Si [82]. 373

4. CONCLUSIONS 383
Waste to energy or material is becoming increasingly important. In this context, waste biomass of 384
RH is being considered as a sustainable and renewable energy resource and has high potential as 385
low cost precursors for the production of value added materials. Harvesting silica or silicon from 386
RH can not only take full advantage of its highest potential value, but also minimize the related 387
environmental issues from the valorization of RH. Thermochemical processes such as pyrolysis, 388
gasification is considered as the most promising approach that can converted RH to biofuels and 389
biochars simultaneously. RH-derived silicon materials could become standard ingredients for LIBs. 390
RH silica may be utilized in future applications such as surface functionalized mesoporous silica, 391
development of hybrid mesoporous silica, synthesis of fluorescent silica particles, antireflective 392
optical coatings, addition of CNTs to mesoporous silica, and nanoparticles supported on silica. 393 394 RH amorphous silica could be synthesized to crystal silicon for battery materials (e.g., LIBs) via 395
carbothermal or magnesiothermic reduction performed at a relatively lower temperature. The 396
fabrication of Si anode materials by using biomass resources enables the effective utilization of 397
agricultural residues in battery industries. The RH-derived Si nanoparticles always suffer from a 398
low coulombic efficiency in the initial charge/discharge and limited cycle life as anode materials 399
due to high surface reactions and low thermodynamic stability. Based on the reported works, the 400
fabrication of Si nanomaterials with nano/micro-hierarchical structure would be an ideal way to 401
improve their electrochemical performances, since the materials on the micrometer size possess 402
a good thermodynamic stability upon cycling. Embedding nano-Si into 3D conductive matrix is an 403
effective way to improve the structure stability and form stable SEI films on surfaces. Among 404
various Si/carbon composite materials, CNT will become a promising matrix because of the wired 405
Page 20 of 38
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
21
morphology, high electronic conductivity, and robust structure. Additionally, CNTs can easily form 406
3D cross-linked conducting networks that ensure effective electron transportation among active 407
particles. Consequently, Si anode materials with nano/micro-hierarchical structure, in which CNTs 408
are tightly intertwined between the RH-derived Si nanoparticles, are supposed to be ideal anode 409
materials for LIBs. In summary, the amorphous silica-rich RH can become a potential resource of 410
low cost precursors for the fabrication of high value-added silicon nanomaterials in battery anode 411
applications. 412 413 AUTHOR INFORMATION 414
